input: Last video I left you with a puzzle.
The setup involves two sliding blocks in a perfectly idealized world where there's no friction and all collisions are perfectly elastic, meaning no energy is lost.
from_community_srt: In ultimul videoclip v-am lasat cu un puzzle Enuntul se serveste de doua corpuri care aluneca intr-o lume ideala in care nu exista frecare si toate coliziunile sunt perfect elastice ceea ce inseamna ca energia nu se pierde

input: One block is sent towards another smaller one, which starts off stationary and there's a wall behind it, so that the smaller block bounces back and forth until it redirects the big block's momentum enough to fully turn around, sailing away from the wall.
from_community_srt: Unul dintre corpuri este trimis in directia celuilalt mai mic care este la inceput in repaus si are un perete in spate astfel incat corpul mai mic sa ricoșeze inainte si inapoi pana cand redirectioneaza impulsul corpului mare suficient incat sa il impinga dinspre perete

input: If that first block has a mass which is a power of 100 times the mass of the second, for example a million times as much, an insanely surprising fact popped out.
from_community_srt: Daca acel prim bloc are o masa ce este o putere a unei mase de o suta de ori mai mare decat a primului De exemplu de 1,000,000 de ori mai mare, un lucru extraordinar de interesant a iesit la suprafata.

input: The total number of collisions, including those between the second mass and the wall, has the same starting digits as pi.
from_community_srt: Numarul total de coliziuni, incluzandu-le pe acelea dintre cel de-al doilea corp si perete, au aceleasi cifre ca pi.

input: In this example that's 3141 collisions.
from_community_srt: In acest exemplu,

input: If that first block was a trillion times the mass, it would be 3,141,592 collisions before this happens.
from_community_srt: asta inseamna 3,141 coliziuni Daca masa ar fi fost de un trilion de ori mai mare, ar fi necesare 3,141,592 coliziuni inainte ca asta sa se intample,

input: Almost all of which happen in one huge unrealistic burst.
from_community_srt: majoritatea intamplandu-se intr-o singura mare izbucnire Apropo de explozii neasteptate,

input: And speaking of unexpectedly big bursts, in the short time since that video went out, lots of people have been sharing solutions and attempts and simulations, which is awesome.
from_community_srt: in scurtul timp de la acel videoclip foarte multi oameni au trimis solutii, incercari si simulari, ceea ce este super. Uita-te in descriere pentru cateva dintre favoritele mele.

input: So why does this happen?
from_community_srt: Deci, de ce se intampla asta?

input: Why should pi show up in such an unexpected place and in such an unexpected manner?
from_community_srt: De ce apare pi intr-un loc atat de neasteptat, si intr-un mod atat de neasteptat? In primul si in primul rand,

input: Foremost this is a lesson about using phase space, also commonly called configuration space, to solve problems.
from_community_srt: asta este o lectie despre utilizarea spatiului fazelor, de asemenea numit un spatiu de configurare, pentru a rezolva probleme.

input: So rest assured that you're not just learning about some esoteric algorithm for pi, this tactic here is core to many other fields, and is a useful tool to keep in your belt.
from_community_srt: Deci nu inveti doar despre un algoritm ezoteric de aflare a lui pi, tactica de aici este centrul a multe alte domenii Pentru inceput,

input: To start, when one block hits another, how do you figure out the velocity of each one after the collision?
from_community_srt: cand unul dintr corpuri il loveste pe celalalt, cum calculezi viteza fiecaruia dupa coliziune?

input: The key is to use the conservation of energy together with the conservation of momentum.
from_community_srt: Cheia este sa folosesti conservarea energiei, si conservarea impulsului.

input: Let's call their masses m1 and m2, and their velocities v1 and v2, which will be the variables changing throughout the process.
from_community_srt: Haide sa le notam masele cu m1 si m2, si vitezele cu v1 si v2,

input: At any given point, the total kinetic energy is ½ m1 v1² plus ½ m2 v2².
from_community_srt: care vor fi variabile ce se vor schimba in timpul procesului in orice moment, energia cinetica totala este (½)m1(v1)^2 + (½)m2(v2)^2.

input: So even though v1 and v2 will be changing as the blocks get bumped around, the value of this expression must remain constant.
from_community_srt: Desi v1 si v2 se vor schimba cand corpurile sunt impinse, valoarea acestei expresii trebuie sa ramana constanta.

input: The total momentum of the two blocks is m1v1 plus m2v2.
from_community_srt: Impulsul total a celor doua corpuri este  m1*v1 + m2*v2.

input: This also has to remain constant when the blocks hit each other, but it can change as the second block bounces off the wall.
from_community_srt: Si acest lucru ramane constant cand cele doua corpuri sa lovesc, dar se poate schimba cand al doilea corp se loveste de perete.

input: In reality, the second block would transfer its momentum to the wall during this collision, and again we're being idealistic, say thinking of that wall as having infinite mass, so such a momentum transfer won't actually move the wall.
from_community_srt: In realitate, acel corp si-ar transfera impulsul catre perete in timpul acestei coliziuni. Din nou suntem idealisti, deci vom spune ca peretele are masa infinita,

input: So here we have two equations and two unknowns.
from_community_srt: deci un astfel de transfer de impuls nu va muta cu adevarat peretele Deci avem doua ecuatii si doua necunoscute. Pentru a le utiliza,

input: To put these to use, try drawing a picture to represent the equations.
You might start by focusing on the energy equation.
from_community_srt: incearca sa desenezi o imagine care sa reprezinte ecuatiile Ai putea incepe prin a te concentra pe ecuatia pentru energie.

input: Since v1 and v2 are changing, maybe you think to represent the equation on a coordinate plane where x is equal to v1 and y is equal to v2.
from_community_srt: Avand in vedere ca v1 si v2 se modifica, poate te gandesti sa reprezinti aceasta ecuatie pe un plan de coordonate, unde coordonata x sa reprezinte v1, si coordonata y sa reprezinte v2.

input: So individual points on this plane encode the pair of velocities of our block.
from_community_srt: Deci punctele individuale din acest plan codifica perechile de viteze ale corpului nostru.

input: In that case, the energy equation represents an ellipse, where each point of this ellipse gives you a pair of velocities, all of which correspond to the same total kinetic energy.
from_community_srt: In acest caz, ecuatia energiei reprezinta o elipsa, unde fiecare punct de pe aceasta elipsa iti da o pereche de viteze, iar toate punctele acestei elipse corespund aceluiasi total de energie cinetica.

input: In fact, let's change our coordinates a little bit to make this a perfect circle, since we know we're on a hunt for pi.
from_community_srt: De fapt, haide sa schimbam coordonatele noastre putin pentru a crea acest cerc perfect, deoarece stim ca ne uitam dupa pi.

input: Instead of having the x-coordinate represent v1, let it be the square root of m1 times v1, which for this example stretches the figure in the x-direction by the square root of 10.
from_community_srt: In loc sa avem o coordonata x pentru a reprezenta v1, sa o facem  sqrt(m1)*v1, care in exemplul nostru intinde figura in directia x cu sqrt(10).

input: Likewise, have the y-coordinate represent square root of m2 times v2.
from_community_srt: In acelasi mod, coordonata y va reprezenta sqrt(m2)*v2.

input: That way, when you look at the conservation of energy equation, what it's saying is ½ x2 plus y2 equals some constant, which is the equation for a circle, which specific circle depends on the total energy, but that doesn't matter for our problem.
from_community_srt: Astfel, cand te uiti la ecuatia de conservare a energiei, spune ca ½(x^2 + y^2) = (o constanta), care este ecuatia unui cerc. Care cerc anume depinde de energia totala. La inceput,

input: At the beginning, when the first block is sliding to the left and the second one is stationary, we're at the leftmost point on the circle, where the x-coordinate is negative and the y-coordinate is zero.
from_community_srt: cand primul corp aluneca catre stanga si cel de-al doilea este in repaus, suntem in acest punct de extrema stanga pe cerc, unde coordonata x  este negativa si coordonata y este 0.

input: What about right after the collision?
from_community_srt: Dar ce se intampla dupa coliziune,

input: How do we know what happens?
Conservation of energy tells us that we must jump to some other point of the circle, but which one?
from_community_srt: cum putem afla? Conservatia energiei ne spune ca trebuie sa sarim pe un alt punct al acestui cerc,

input: Use the conservation of momentum.
from_community_srt: dar care? Pai, haide sa folosim conservarea impulsului!

input: This tells us that before and after the collision, the value of m1 times v1 plus m2 times v2 must stay constant.
from_community_srt: Aceasta ne spune ca inainte si dupa o coliziune valoarea m1*v1 + m2*v2 trebuie sa ramana constanta.

input: In our rescaled coordinates, that looks like saying square root of m1 times x plus square root of m2 times y equals some constant.
from_community_srt: In coordonatele noastre redimensionate, asta arata ca a spune ca sqrt(m1)*x + sqrt(m2)*y = (o constanta),

input: And that's the equation for a line, specifically a line with a slope of negative square root of m1 over m2.
from_community_srt: care este ecuatia pentru o linie cu inclinatia -sqrt(m1/m2).

input: You might ask which specific line, and that depends on what the constant momentum is, but we know that it must pass through our first point, and that locks us into one choice.
from_community_srt: Care linie specifica depinde de care este impulsul constant. Dar stim ca trebuie sa treaca prin primul nostru punct,

input: So just to be clear about what all this is saying, all other pairs of velocities which would give the same momentum live on this line, in just the same way that all other pairs of velocities that give the same energy live on this circle.
from_community_srt: ceea ce ne blocheaza in loc. Ca sa fim clari: orice alta pereche de viteze care ar da acelasi impuls se afla pe linia asta, in acelasi mod in care toate celelalte perechi de viteze care dau aceeasi energie se afla pe cercul nostru.

input: So notice, this gives us one and only one other point that we could jump to.
from_community_srt: Deci, dupa cum vezi, asta ne da un singur alt punct catre care am putea sari.

input: And it should make sense that it's something where the x-coordinate gets a little less negative and the y-coordinate becomes negative, since that corresponds to the big block, which is slowing down a little, while the little block zooms off towards the wall.
from_community_srt: Si are sens ca acel loc sa fie un loc in care coordonata x este mai putin negativa si coordonata y este negativa, deoarece asta corespunde incetinirii corpului nostru mai mare in timp ce corpul mai mic se indreapta catre perete

input: From here it's quite fun to see how things play out.
When the second block bounces off the wall, its speed stays the same, but it goes from negative to positive, right?
from_community_srt: cand cel de-al doilea corp ricoșeaza, viteza lui ramane aceeasi, dar va trece de la negativa la pozitiva.

input: So in this diagram, that corresponds to reflecting about the x-axis, since the y-coordinate gets multiplied by negative 1.
from_community_srt: In aceasta diagrama, asta corespunde cu reflectia axei x deoarece coordonata y este inmultita cu -1.

input: Then once more, the next collision corresponds to a jump along a line with slope negative square root of m1 over m2, since staying on such a line is what conservation of momentum looks like in this diagram.
from_community_srt: Si apoi tot in acelasi mod, urmatoarea coliziune ii corespunde unei sarituri pe linia de inclinatia -sqrt(m1 / m2), deoarece sa ramana pe o astfel de linie este cum arata conservarea impulsului in aceasta diagrama

input: And from here you can fill in the rest for how the block collisions correspond to hopping around the circle in our picture, where we keep going like this, until the velocity of that smaller block is both positive and smaller than the velocity of the big one, meaning they'll never touch again.
from_community_srt: Asta ne da o imagine foarte satisfacatoarea a cum putem sari inainte si inapoi pe imaginea noastra, unde continui pana cand viteza corpului mai mic este si pozitiva, si mai mica decat viteza celui mare, ceea ce inseamna ca nu se vor mai atinge niciodata.

input: That corresponds to this triangular region in the upper right of the diagram, so in our region.
from_community_srt: Asta corespunde cu regiunea asta a diagramei, deci in procesul nostru,

input: What we've drawn here is called a phase diagram, which is a simple but powerful idea in math where you encode the state of some system, in this case the velocities of our sliding blocks, as a single point in some abstract space.
from_community_srt: continuam sa sarim pana ajungem in acea regiune. Ce am desenat aici se numeste o diagrama  a fazelor, ce este o simpla dar puternica idee in matematica conform careia poti codifica starea unui sistem, in acest caz vitezele corpurilor noastre, ca un singur punct intr-un spatiu abstract.

input: What's powerful here is that it turns questions about dynamics into questions about geometry.
from_community_srt: Lucrul puternic aici este ca transforma intrebarile despre dinamica in intrebari despre geometrie.

input: In this case, the dynamical idea of all possible pairs of velocities that conserve energy corresponds to the geometric idea of a circle, and counting the total number of collisions turns into counting the total number of hops along these lines, alternating between vertical and diagonal.
from_community_srt: In acest caz, ideea dinamica a tuturor perechilor de viteze care conserva energie corespunde obiectului geometric al unui cerc, iar numararea coliziunilor se transforma in numararea sariturilor pe aceste linii,

input: But our question remains, why is it that when that mass ratio is a power of 100, the total number of steps shows the digits of pi?
from_community_srt: alternand intre vertical si diagonal. Mai specific, de ce atunci cand raportul maselor este o putere a lui 100, acel numar de pasi arata cifrele lui pi? Daca privesti imaginea,

input: Well, if you stare at this picture, maybe, just maybe, you'd notice that all the arc lengths between the points on this circle seem to be about the same.
from_community_srt: poate, doar poate, vei reusi sa vezi ca toate lungimile arcelor dintre punctele acestui cerc par sa fie aproximativ aceleasi.

input: It's not immediately obvious that this should be true, but if it is, it means that computing the value of one such arc length should be enough to figure out how many total collisions it takes to get us into that end zone.
from_community_srt: Nu este imediat evident ca asta este adevarat, dar daca este, asta inseamna ca calcularea valorii acelei lungimi de arc ar trebui sa fie suficienta pentru a calcula de cate coliziuni ai nevoie pentru a face inconjurul

input: The key here is to use the ever-helpful inscribed angle theorem, which says that whenever you're forming an angle using three points on a circle, P1, P2, and P3, like this, it will be exactly half of the angle formed by P1, the circle's center, and P3.
from_community_srt: cercului catre zona de sfarsit Cheia aici este sa folosim teorema unghiului inscris, care spune ca atunci cand formezi un unghi folosind trei puncte pe un cerc P1, P2 si P3 ca aici, va fi exact jumatate din unghiul format de P1, centrul cercului,

input: P2 can be anywhere on this circle, anywhere except between P1 and P3, and this lovely little fact will be true.
from_community_srt: si P3. P2 poate fi oriunde pe acest cerc, exceptand in arcul dintre P1 si P3,

input: So now look back at our phase space, and focus specifically on three points, like these.
from_community_srt: si acest lucru va fi adevarat. Deci acum ne vom uita la spatiul fazelor, si ne vom concentra pe cele trei puncte ca acestea.

input: Remember that first vertical hop corresponds to the second block bouncing off the wall, and that second hop, along a slope of negative square root of m1 over m2, corresponds to a momentum-conserving block collision.
from_community_srt: Aminteste-ti ca prima saritura verticala corespunde coliziunii corpului mic cu peretele, si a doua saritura pe inclinatia -sqrt(m1 / m2) corespunde coliziunii unor corpuri care conserva

input: Let's call the angle between this momentum line and the vertical line theta, and now maybe you see it using the inscribed angle theorem, this arc length between those two bottom points, measured in radians, will be 2 theta.
from_community_srt: impulsul. Haide sa notam unghiul dintre aceasta linie si verticala „theta”. Apoi, folosind teorema unghiului inscris, lungimea arcului dintre aceste doua puncte, masurata in radiani, va fi 2*theta. Observa ca,

input: And importantly, since the momentum line has the same slope for all of those jumps from the top of the circle to the bottom, the same reasoning means that all of these arc lengths must also be 2 theta.
from_community_srt: deoarece aceasta linie de impuls are aceeasi inclinatie pentru toate sariturile din partea de sus a cercului in jos, acelasi rationament inseamna ca toate aceste arce trebuie sa fie de asemenea 2*theta Deci pentru fiecare saritura,

input: So for each hop, if we drop down a new arc, like so, then after each collision we cover another 2 theta radians of the circle.
from_community_srt: daca coboram pe un nou arc asa, atunci dupa fiecare coliziune acoperim inca 2*theta radiani din cerc.

input: We stop once we're in the end zone on the right, which remember corresponds to both blocks moving to the right with the smaller one going slower.
from_community_srt: Ne oprim odata ce ajungem in zona de sfarsit, care corespunde cu ambele blocuri aluncecand catre dreapta, cu cel mai mic alunecand mai incet.

input: But you can also think of this as stopping at the point when adding one more arc of 2 theta would overlap with the previous one.
from_community_srt: Dar poti sa te gandesti la asta ca la oprirea in punctul in care adaugarea a inca un arc 2*theta acesta s-ar

input: In other words, how many times do you have to add 2 theta to itself before it covers more than the whole circle, more than 2 pi radians?
from_community_srt: suprapune cu unul de dinainte In alte cuvinte, de cate ori trebuie sa adaugi 2*theta la sine pana cand acopera mai mult de 2*pi radiani?

input: The answer to this will be the same as the number of collisions between our blocks.
from_community_srt: Raspunsul este acelasi cu numarul de coliziuni dintre corpurile noastre Sau,

input: Or to say the same thing more compactly, what's the largest integer multiple of theta that doesn't surpass pi?
from_community_srt: simplificand lucrurile putin, care este cel mai mare multiplu intreg al lui theta care nu depaseste pi? De exemplu,

input: For example, if theta was 0.01 radians, then multiplying it by as much as 314 would keep you below pi, but multiplying by 315 would bring you over that value.
from_community_srt: daca theta ar fi 0.01 radiani, atunci multiplicarea cu 314 ti-ar da mai putin decat pi, dar inmultirea cu 315 te-ar duce peste valoarea aceea.

input: So the answer would be 314, meaning if our mass ratio was one such that the angle theta in our diagram was 0.01, then the blocks would collide 314 times.
from_community_srt: Deci raspunsul va fi 314, ceea ce inseamna ca daca raportul maselor noastre ar fi in asa fel incat unghiul theta din diagrama noastra ar fi 0.01, corpurile ar coliziona de 314 ori De fapt,

input: So now you know what we need to do.
from_community_srt: haide sa calculam theta,

input: Let's go ahead and actually compute the value theta, say when the mass ratio is 100 to 1.
from_community_srt: sa zicem atunci cand raportul dintre mase este 100:1.

input: Remember, this rise over run slope of that constant momentum line was the negative square root of m1 over m2, which in this example is negative 10.
from_community_srt: Tine minte ca panta ascendenta a acestei linii de impuls constant este  -sqrt(m1/m2), care in acest exemplu este -10.

input: That would mean that the tangent of this angle theta, opposite over adjacent, is the run over the negative rise, so to speak, which is 1 divided by 10 in this example.
from_community_srt: Asta ar insemna ca tangenta acestui unghi theta, opusa pe alaturata este acea panta ascendenta supra cresterea negativa, care este 1/10 in acest exemplu.

input: So theta is going to be the arctan of 1 tenth.
from_community_srt: Deci theta = arctan(1/10) In general,

input: Speaking more generally, it'll be the inverse tangent of the square root of the small mass over the square root of the big mass.
from_community_srt: va fi inversul tangetei radicalului din masa mica pe radicalul masei mari Daca le introduci intr-un calculator,

input: If you plug these into a calculator, what you'd notice is that the inverse tangent of such a small value is actually quite close to the value itself.
from_community_srt: vei observa ca arctanul pentru fiecare dintre aceste valori asa de mici va fi aproape de valoare in sine.

input: For example, arctan of 1 over 100, corresponding to a big mass of 10,000 kg, is extremely close to 0.01.
from_community_srt: De exemplu, arctan(1/100) corespunzand unei mase mari de 10,000 kilograme, este foarte aproape de 0.01.

input: In fact, it's so close that for the sake of our central question, it might as well be 0.01.
from_community_srt: De fapt, e atat de aproape incat, pentru intrebarea noastra principala, ar putea fi la fel de bine 0.01.

input: What I mean by that is, analogous to what we saw a moment ago, adding this to itself as many as 314 times won't surpass pi, but the 315th time would.
from_community_srt: Asta insemnand ca, analog cu ce am vazut mai devreme, adunarea sa cu sine de 314 ori nu va depasi pi, dar a 315-a oara ar face-o.

input: Remember, unraveling why we're doing all this, that's a way of counting how many jumps on the phase diagram gets us into the end zone, which in turn is a way of counting how many times the blocks collide until they're sailing off to never touch again.
from_community_srt: Aminteste-ti, lamurind de ce facem asta, asta e un mod de a numara de cate sarituri pe diagrama avem nevoie pentru a ajunge la zona de final, ceea ce e un mod de a numara de cate ori corpurile colizioneaza inainte de a aluneca fara sa se mai atinga vreodata.

input: So that, my friends, is why a mass ratio of 10,000 gives 314 collisions.
from_community_srt: Deci de aceea un raport de masa de 10,000 da 314 coliziuni In acelasi mod,

input: Likewise, a mass ratio of a million to one will give an angle theta equals the inverse tangent of 1 over 1000.
from_community_srt: un raport de 1,000,000 la 1 va da un unghi de arctan(1/1,000) in diagrama noastra.

input: This is extremely close to 0.001.
from_community_srt: Asta este foarte aproape de 0.001. Si, din nou,

input: And again, if we ask about the largest integer multiple of this angle that doesn't surpass pi, it's the same as it would be for a precise value of 0.001, namely 3141.
from_community_srt: daca intrebam de cel mai mare multiplu intreg al acestui theta care nu depaseste pi, este la fel ca pentru valoarea precisa de 0.001: 3.141. Acestea sunt primele patru cifre ale lui pi,

input: These are the first four digits of pi because that is, by definition, what digits of a number mean.
from_community_srt: pentru ca asta este definitia sensului cifrelor lui pi.

input: This explains why when the mass ratio is a million, the number of collisions is 3141.
from_community_srt: Asta explica de ce, cu un raport al maselor de 1,000,000,

input: And you might notice that all of this relies on the hope that the inverse tangent of a small value is sufficiently close to the value itself, which is another way of saying that the tangent of a small value is approximately that value itself.
from_community_srt: numarul de coliziuni este 3,141 Toate astea se bazeaza pe speranta ca arctan al unei valori mici este suficient de apropiat de valoare in sine, ceea ce este un alt mod de a spune ca tangenta unei valori mici este aproximativ valoarea respectiva.

input: Intuitively, there's a really nice reason this is true.
from_community_srt: Intuitiv, exista un motiv bun pentru ca asta sa fie adevarat.

input: If you look at a unit circle, the tangent of any given angle is the height of this little triangle I've drawn divided by its width.
from_community_srt: Daca ne uitam la un cerc unitar, tangenta oricarui unghi este inaltimea acestui triunghi impartita la latimea sa.

input: And when that angle is really small, the width is basically 1, the radius of your circle, and the height is basically the same as the arc length along that circle, and by definition that arc length is theta.
from_community_srt: Cand unghiul este foarte mic, latimea este practic 1, iar inaltimea este practic aceeasi cu lungimea arcului pe cerc, care prin definitie este theta.

input: To be more precise about it, the Taylor series expansion of tangent of theta shows that this approximation will have only a cubic error term.
from_community_srt: Ca sa fim precisi, expansiunea seriei Taylor pentru tan(theta) arata ca aceasta aproximatie va avea doar o eroare de ordin cubic.

input: So for example, the tangent of 1 one hundredth differs from 1 one hundredth itself by something on the order of 1 one millionth.
from_community_srt: Deci de exemplu, tan(1/100) difera de 1/100 cu ceva de ordinul 1/1,000,000.

input: So even if we were to consider 314 steps with this angle, the error between the actual value of arc tan 1 over 100 and the approximation of 0.01 just won't have a chance to accumulate high enough to be as big as an integer.
from_community_srt: Deci chiar daca consideram 314 pasi cu acest unghi, eroarea dintre valoarea lui arctan(1/100) si aproximatia lui 0.01 nu va avea sansa de a se acumula suficient incat sa fie signifianta.

input: So let's zoom out and sum up.
from_community_srt: Deci, haide sa micsoram imaginea si sa concluzionam:

input: When blocks collide, you can figure out their new velocities by slicing a line through a circle in a velocity phase diagram, where each of these curves represents a conservation law.
from_community_srt: Cand doua corpuri colizioneaza, le poti afla vitezele taind un cerc intr-o diagrama a fazelor pentru viteza, fiecare curba reprezentand o lege a conservarii.

input: Most notably, the conservation of energy is what plants that circular seed that ultimately blossoms into the pi that we find in the final count.
from_community_srt: Cel mai important, conservarea energiei planteaza samanta circulara care va inflori in pi-ul pe care il gasim in numaratoare

input: Specifically, due to some inscribed angle geometry, the points that we hit of this circle are spaced out evenly, separated by an angle we were calling 2 theta.
from_community_srt: Specific, datorita geometriei unghiului inscris, punctele pe care le atingem pe cerc sunt distribuite uniform, separate de unghiul numit 2*theta.

input: This lets us rephrase the question of counting collisions, as instead asking how many times must we add 2 theta to itself before it surpasses 2 pi.
from_community_srt: Asta ne lasa sa refrazam intrebarea numararii coliziunilor ca in loc sa intrebam de cate ori trebuie sa adaugam 2*theta la sine inainte de a trece de 2pi.

input: If theta looks something like 0.001, the answer to that question has the same first digits as pi, and when the mass ratio is some power of 100, because arc tan of x is so well approximated by x for small values, theta is sufficiently close to this value that it gives the same final count.
from_community_srt: Daca theta este similar cu 0.001, raspunsul la aceasta intrebare are aceleasi prime cifre ca pi. Si cand raportul maselor este o putere a lui 100, deoarece arctan(x) este asa de bine aproximat de x pentru valori mici, theta este suficient de apropiat de aceasta valoare pentru a da aceeasi numaratoare finala.

input: I'll emphasize again what this phase space allowed us to do, because as I said, this is a lesson useful for all sorts of math, like differential equations, chaos theory, and other flavors of dynamics.
from_community_srt: In contextul urmatorului videoclip Voi sublinia din nou ce ne-a permis spatiul fazelor sa facem, pentru ca asta e o lectie folositoare pentru mai multe domenii ale matematicii, ca ecuatiile diferentiale, teoria haosului, si alte feluri de dinamica.

input: By representing the relevant state of your system as a single point in an abstract space, it lets you translate problems of dynamics into problems of geometry.
from_community_srt: Reprezentand starea sistemului relevanta ca un singur punct intr-un spatiu abstract, poti transforma probleme de dinamica in probleme de geometrie.

input: I repeat myself because I don't want you to come away just remembering a neat puzzle where pi shows up unexpectedly, I want you to remember this surprise appearance as a distilled remnant of the deeper relationship at play.
from_community_srt: Ma repet deoarece nu vreau sa plecati doar amintindu-va de un puzzle interesant unde pi apare in mod neasteptat, ci vreau sa va ganditi la aparitia surpriza ca la un vestigiu al relatiei mai profunde in joc.

input: And if this solution leaves you feeling satisfied, it shouldn't, because there is another perspective, more clever and pretty than this one, due to Galperin and his original paper on this phenomenon, which invites us to draw a striking parallel between the dynamics of these blocks and that of a beam of light bouncing between two mirrors.
from_community_srt: Si daca solutia asta te satisface, nu ar trebui sa o faca. Pentru ca mai este o perspectiva, mai inteligenta si draguta decat asta, curtoazie lui Galperin in lucrarea originala despre acest fenomen, care ne invita sa comparam dinamica dintre aceste corpuri si aceea a unei raze de lumina ricosand intre doua oglinzi.

input: Trust me, I've saved the best for last on this topic, so I hope to see you again in the next video.
from_community_srt: Crede-ma, am pastrat ce-i mai bun la sfarsit in acest subiect, deci sper sa te vad si in urmatorul videoclip.
